close_symbols: OS_SUCCESS (and other return-code macros used by OS_TranslatePath/OS_chmod)
explanation: 1) OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN - The local buffer size (char local_path[OS_MAX_LOCAL_PATH_LEN]) is needed to determine whether any string operations performed on local_path can write or read past its bounds. 2) OS_TranslatePath (full implementation / prototype) - OS_chmod passes local_path to this function; its implementation determines whether it copies or appends strings into local_path and which <string.h> functions (or wrappers) it uses and whether it performs proper bounds checks. 3) OS_strnlen (implementation/wrapper) - OS_TranslatePath calls OS_strnlen (a string helper). You must inspect whether OS_strnlen maps to a safe standard function (strnlen/strlen) and how its length limits are used in subsequent copy/append operations to assess possible out-of-bounds access. 4) OS_FileChmod_Impl (prototype and implementation) - After a successful translation, local_path is handed to this function; its implementation may perform further string operations on local_path (reads or writes) that could violate bounds, so it must be checked. 5) OS_SUCCESS (and other return-code macros used by OS_TranslatePath/OS_chmod) - The control flow (whether OS_FileChmod_Impl is called) depends on these codes; to reason about which code paths (and thus which string operations) can actually execute you need the exact definitions of these return values.
